medical_history.chief_complaint: Hypocalcemic seizures at 6 weeks of life.
medical_history.history_of_present_illness: The first sibling presented with hypocalcemic seizures at 6 weeks of life, with serum calcium at 1.32 mmol/liter and magnesium at 0.48 mmol/liter. Her symptoms were alleviated with calcium and vitamin D supplements, which were stopped at 1 year of age. At 4 years of age, she was brought to medical attention again due to inconsolable crying at night, leading to the diagnosis of FHHNC. The second sibling presented at age 12 with macroscopic hematuria and flank pain and was found to have a right ureteric stone and dense nephrocalcinosis.
medical_history.past_medical_history: Both siblings diagnosed with familial hypomagnesemia with hypercalciuria and nephrocalcinosis (FHHNC). The first sibling experienced neonatal hypocalcemic seizures. The second sibling had right ureteric stones leading to multiple lithotripsy procedures.
medical_history.family_history: The parents are from the same village in Pakistan but are not knowingly related. A third sibling was screened and found to have normal renal ultrasound and serum chemistry.
